The shades of night were scarcely fled;</br>The air was mild, the winds were still;</br>And slow the slanting sun-beams spread</br>O'er wood and lawn, o'er heath and hill.
From fleecy clouds of pearly hue</br>Had dropp'd a short but balmy shower,</br>That hung, like gems of morning dew,</br>On every tree and every flower.
And from the Blackbird's mellow throat</br>Was pour'd so loud and long a swell,</br>As echoed with responsive note</br>From mountain side, and shadowy dell.
When, bursting forth to life and light,</br>The offspring of enraptur'd May,</br>The Butterfly, on pinions bright,</br>Launch'd in full splendour on the day.
Unconscious of a mother's care,</br>No infant wretchedness she knew;</br>But, as she felt the vernal air,</br>At once to full perfection grew.
Her slender form, ethereal, light,</br>Her velvet-textur'd wings unfold;</br>With all the rainbow's colours bright</br>And dropt with spots of burnish'd gold.
Trembling with joy, awhile she stood,</br>And felt the sun's enlivening ray;</br>Drank from the skies the vital flood,</br>And wonder'd at her plumage gay;
And balanc'd oft her broider'd wings,</br>Through fields of air prepar'd to sail;</br>Then on her ven'trous journey springs,</br>And floats along the rising gale.
Go, child of Pleasure, range the fields,</br>Taste all the joys that Spring can give,</br>Partake what bounteous Summer yields,</br>And live, while yet 'tis thine to live.
Go, sip the rose's fragrant dew,</br>The lily's honey'd cup explore.</br>From flower to flower the search renew,</br>And rifle all the woodbine's store;
And let me trace thy vagrant flight,</br>Thy moments too of short repose,</br>And mark thee then with fresh delight</br>Thy golden pinions ope and close.
But hark!  while thus I musing stand,</br>Pours on the gale an airy note;</br>And, breathing from a viewless band,</br>Soft silvery tones around me float!
—They cease — but still a voice I hear,</br>A whisper'd voice of hope and joy,</br>"Thy hour of rest approaches near,</br>Prepare thee, mortal!  — thou must die!
"Yet start not; — on thy closing eyes</br>Another day shall still unfold,</br>A sun of milder radiance rise,</br>A happier age of joys untold.
"Shall the poor worm that shocks thy sight,</br>The humblest form in Nature's train,</br>Thus rise in new-born lustre bright,</br>And yet the emblem teach in vain?
"Ah!  where were once her golden eyes,</br>Her glittering wings of purple pride?</br>Conceal'd beneath a rude disguise,</br>A shapeless mass to earth allied.
"Like thee the hapless reptile liv'd,</br>Like thee he toil'd, like thee he spun,</br>Like thine his closing hour arriv'd,</br>His labours ceas'd, his web was done.
"And shalt thou, number'd with the dead,</br>No happier state of being know?</br>And shall no future morrow shed</br>On thee a beam of brighter glow?
"In this the bound of Power Divine,</br>To animate an insect frame?</br>Or shall not He who moulded thine,</br>Wake at his will the vital flame?
"— Go, mortal! — in thy reptile state,</br>Enough to know thee is given;</br>Go, and the joyful truth relate,</br>Frail Child of Earth!  high Heir of Heaven!"</br>
